Sure, here's a table that elaborates on the activities and provides examples for the lesson plan on colors for 5 to 7-year-olds:

| Activity | Objective | Materials | Procedure | Example |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Introduction | To introduce the concept of colors and primary and secondary colors | Color wheel poster or printout | Show the color wheel poster or printout and explain that colors can be divided into primary colors (red, blue, and yellow) and secondary colors (orange, green, and purple) | Red, blue, and yellow are the primary colors. Orange, green, and purple are the secondary colors. |
| Activity 1: Identifying Colors | To identify and name primary and secondary colors | White paper, paint or colored markers, paintbrushes or markers | Give each student a sheet of white paper and a set of markers or paints. Ask them to color the paper with the primary colors and the secondary colors. As they work, ask them to identify the colors they are using. | Red, blue, and yellow are the primary colors. Orange, green, and purple are the secondary colors. |
| Activity 2: Mixing Colors | To explore mixing primary colors to create secondary colors | White paper, paint or colored markers, paintbrushes or markers | Explain to the students that by mixing primary colors, they can create secondary colors. Give each student a new sheet of white paper and ask them to mix the primary colors to create secondary colors. Encourage them to experiment with different ratios of colors to create different shades. | Red + blue = purple, blue + yellow = green, red + yellow = orange |
| Activity 3: Color Hunt | To identify colors in everyday objects | Small items of different colors, color wheel poster or printout | Hide small items of different colors around the classroom or outside. Ask the students to find the items and match them to the corresponding color on the color wheel. | A red apple, a blue pen, a yellow pencil, a green leaf, an orange pumpkin |
| Assessment | To assess the students' understanding of primary and secondary colors and mixing colors | Color wheel poster or printout, picture of an object, paint or colored markers, paintbrushes or markers | Ask the students to point out the primary colors and the secondary colors on the color wheel. Show them a picture of an object and ask them to name the color of the object. Ask the students to mix two primary colors to create a secondary color. | What two primary colors do you mix to make green? What color is a banana? What two primary colors do you mix to make purple? |
| Extension | To extend the lesson by introducing warm and cool colors | Blank circle, paint or colored markers, paintbrushes or markers | Give them a blank circle and ask them to divide it into six equal parts. Label each part with a warm or cool color and have them color each part accordingly. Ask them to create a painting using only warm or cool colors. | Warm colors: red, orange, yellow. Cool colors: blue, green, purple. A warm-colored painting could be a sunset, while a cool-colored painting could be a winter landscape. |

By incorporating different activities and examples, this lesson plan helps young children understand the concept of colors, identify primary and secondary colors, and explore mixing colors to create new shades. The assessment and extension activities also help assess the students' understanding and extend their knowledge of colors by introducing warm and cool colors.
